Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Exploring Somatic Dimensions of Group Solidarity, Cooperation, and Altruism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the effects of bodily movement within ritual practice on group identity, solidarity, and cooperation as well as both within group and between group altruism. Coordinating with formal laboratory behavioral studies and cultural evolution modeling efforts at University of California, Davis, and University of British Columbia, it employs a unique fusion of community-based participatory action research (PAR), behavioral experiments with game theory, and cognitive anthropology methods. The project takes place among indigenous groups in the U.S. The communities are in a process of rebuilding community and seeing a strong resurgence in traditional ritual dance practice explicitly motivated by identity and solidarity. This creates a rich context for both socially relevant collaborative research and testing of biocultural evolutionary theories of ritual. Recent findings from the field of human behavioral ecology demonstrate how many fundamental human behaviors are adaptions to biological and economic constraints. While employing the human behavioral ecology model, this research will examine a seemingly complex set of behaviors surrounding ritual which until now have relied on abstract methods in anthropology that employ symbolism as an explanatory variable. By disaggregating ritual into a set of testable premises this research is a potential model for the way human behavioral ecology can address other important cultural phenomena that are typically not testable using controlled experiments.

This project investigates several models of ritual function, concentrating on two specific models:

1. Synchrony - physical actions that involve synchronized movement will promote group identification and cooperation and altruism, but only within the group of practitioners.

2. Calming - physical practices which cultivate a state of calm will reduce group identification and promote cooperation and altruism in a broader range of contexts.

This research examines ritual practices that exemplify each of these styles for their effects on both parochialism and universal altruism through qualitative interviews, participant observation, and formal experiments. The PAR framework of the project implies that both method and objective of the project will emerge out of collaboration between the local community and the researchers. This research represents a change in approach for cultural anthropology by studying something experimentally that historically was studied using ethnographic methods. The project also contributes to the education of a graduate student in anthropology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF DDIG funded research on the felt experiences that bring people into commitment to activism and solidarity in the context of the interlocking issues of First Nations sovereignty, fights against environmentally destructive oil and gas development, and cross cultural solidarity, with special focus on blockades and direct action resistance as embodied rituals of solidarity building and commitment to values. Such direct action resistance movements are exemplified by the blockades and land occupation actions that have been happening in British Columbia, Canada, where First Nations groups have been setting up camps to directly block unwanted industrial activity, putting their bodies literally in the way of industry. They involve occupation of the land, building of permanent structures in the proposed paths of industrial activity with help from solidarity partners from other indigenous and non-indigenous communities and incorporating traditional rituals of protocols of sovereignty and naming of responsibilities and thanks to the land. This research specifically looked at the effects of physical participation in these actions on felt sense of commitment to core values through participant observation, interviews of other participants, and collaborative discussions of practice. It also involved interviews with other supportive or involved regional individuals and non-profit organizations and participation in other community rituals of potlaching and festivals. In interviews conducted as part of this research, people drawn into activism speak to the inspiration that they find in direct, physical experience of the environment and the abundance of the sea, rivers, and land in terms of fish and game that feeds them. Those participating in direct action resistance campaigns on the land speak of how simply being on the land together generated a felt experience of the importance of land protection. Further, they speak of the sense of mutual inspiration that they receive from each other in participating in direct action resistance.  The effectiveness in such direct action resistance movements in generating solidarity is demonstrated by the high rate of return to sights of resistance, including from people willing to travel many hundreds of miles and sacrifice weeks of their time in taking part in these actions year after year.

One of the theories that guides these actions is that small groups of devoted actors may cultivate a stronger will to act together in commitment to their values than is possible in mass movements and that in certain contexts, such groups may therefore be more politically effective in protecting the environment and fighting for other social and political values than mass movements. The kinds of transformations of perspective and values that people report happening for themselves in these actions lends support to this theory, which has parallels in contemporary research on both theories of the psychology of the sacred as well as research on intense ritual behavior and human bonding.

The qualitative research in activist contexts supported by this grant supports the extrapolation of models of human psychology generated in the context of religious ritual to other spheres of social organization. Understanding how such small group actions function politically and individually can help groups organize more effectively for socially and environmentally sustainable outcomes that empower group members through effective solidarity.
